sen.j: 阿古御局（おこごのつぼね、天正18年〔1590年〕 - 慶長20年5月8日 (旧暦)〔1615年6月4日〕）は、戦国時代 (日本)から江戸時代初頭にかけて生きた女性。
sen.e: Okogo no Tsubone (1590-June 4, 1615) was a woman who lived over the he Sengoku period (period of warring states) and the early Edo period.
Okogo no Tsubone (1590 - June 4, 1615) was a woman who lived during the Sengoku period (period of warring states) and the early Edo period.
Okogo no Tsubone (1590 - June 4, 1615) was a woman who lived during the Sengoku period (period of warring states) and the early Edo period.

sen.j: 淀殿のちに豊臣秀頼の侍女で大上臈。
sen.e: She was a waiting woman to Yodo-dono (Lady Yodo), and later to Hideyori TOYOTOMI, and ranked as a dai-joro (the upper grade ladies-in-waiting for Sento (the Palace for a Retired Emperor) and Sekkan-ke (the families which produced regents)).

She was a maidservant to Yodo-dono (Lady Yodo), and later to Hideyori TOYOTOMI, and ranked as a dai-joro (the upper grade ladies-in-waiting for Sento (the Palace for a Retired Emperor) and Sekkan-ke (the families which produced regents)).

She was a maidservant to Yodo-dono (Lady Yodo), and later to Hideyori TOYOTOMI, and ranked as a dai-joro (the upper grade ladies-in-waiting for Sento [the Palace for a Retired Emperor] and Sekkan-ke [the families which produced regents]).
sen.cmt: 括弧内の括弧を[]に変更

sen.j: 中将、弁宰相阿古大上臈、和期の方または和期の局（ともに「わご」と読む）とも。
sen.e: She was also called 'Chujo,' 'Bensaisyo Ako Dai-joro,' 'Wago no Kata,' or 'Wago no Tsubone.'
She was also called 'Chujo,' 'Bensaisyo Ako Dai-joro,' 'Wago no Kata,' or 'Wago no Tsubone.'
She was also called 'Chujo,' 'Bensaisyo Ako Dai-joro,' 'Wago no Kata,' or 'Wago no Tsubone.'

sen.j: 名は菊という。
sen.e: Her childhood name was 'Kiku.'
Her childhood name was 'Kiku.'
Her name was 'Kiku.'
sen.cmt: 「菊」はchildhood name ではなく、name です。

sen.j: 父は伊勢貞為（『寛政諸家系図伝』）、伊勢貞景とも。
sen.e: His father was Sadatame ISE (according to "Kansei Compilation of Genealogies of Vassals in Edo Bakufu") while it is also said that her father was Sadakage ISE.
His father was Sadatame ISE (according to "Kansei Compilation of Genealogies of Vassals in Edo Bakufu") while it is also said that her father was Sadakage ISE.

His father was Sadatame ISE (according to "Kansei Compilation of Genealogies of Vassals in Edo Bakufu [Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun]") while it is also said that her father was Sadakage ISE.

sen.j: また伊勢貞良で母は松永久秀の長女もしくは孫娘とも。
sen.e: Another belief is that his father was Sadayoshi ISE, and her mother was the eldest daughter or the granddaughter of Hisahide MATSUNAGA.
Another belief is that his father was Sadayoshi ISE, and her mother was the eldest daughter or the granddaughter of Hisahide MATSUNAGA.
Another belief is that his father was Sadayoshi ISE, and her mother was the eldest daughter or the granddaughter of Hisahide MATSUNAGA.

sen.j: 上臈とは貞観殿、内侍司、および二位、三位の典侍で禁色をゆるされた大臣の女、あるいは孫女などのこと。
sen.e: The word 'joro' refers to court ladies in Joganden (Imperial Residence for Sewing), Naishi no Tsukasa (female secretaries to an emperor), or Naishi no suke (court ladies of higher ranks) of the Second or Third Rank, in other words, the daughters or granddaughters of daijin (councils of the Imperial Court) who were allowed to put on the colors of the Imperial families.

The word 'joro' refers to court ladies in Joganden (Imperial Residence for Sewing), Naishi no Tsukasa (female secretaries to an emperor), or Naishi no suke (court ladies of higher ranks) of the Second or Third Rank, in other words, the daughters or granddaughters of daijin (councils of the Imperial Court) who were allowed to put on the colors of the Imperial families.

The word 'joro' refers to court ladies in Joganden (Imperial Residence for Sewing), Naishi no Tsukasa (female secretaries to an emperor), or Naishi no suke (court ladies of higher ranks) of the Second or Third Rank, in other words, the daughters or granddaughters of daijin (councils of the Imperial Court) who were allowed to put on the colors of the Imperial families.

sen.j: 上臈には『大納言局』、『中納言局』、『左衛門督』、『帥』、『一位局』、『二位局』、『三位局』などとつけ、少々低いところには『按察使』とつける。
sen.e: Joro was commonly called 'Dainagon no Tsubone,' 'Chunagon no Tsubone,' 'Saemon no Kami,' 'Sochi,' 'Ichii no Tsubone,' 'Nii no Tsubone,' 'Sani no Tsubone,' and so on, whereas joro of slightly lower ranks were commonly called 'Azechi.'

Joro was commonly called 'Dainagon no Tsubone,' 'Chunagon no Tsubone,' 'Saemon no Kami,' 'Sochi,' 'Ichii no Tsubone,' 'Nii no Tsubone,' 'Sani no Tsubone,' and so on, whereas joro of slightly lower ranks were commonly called 'Azechi.'

Joro was commonly called "Dainagon no Tsubone," "Chunagon no Tsubone," "Saemon no Kami," "Sochi," "Ichii no Tsubone," "Nii no Tsubone," "Sanmi no Tsubone," and so on, whereas joro of slightly lower ranks were commonly called "Azechi."

sen.j: 三位以上の夫人でも禁色を許されないものは上臈と称することは許されなかった。
sen.e: Even if ladies were ranked the Third Rank and higher, they were prohibited from using the style of joro when they were not allowed to put on the colors of the Imperial families.
Even if ladies were ranked the Third Rank or higher, they were prohibited from using the style of joro if they were not allowed to put on the colors of the Imperial families.
Even if ladies were ranked the Third Rank or higher, they were prohibited from using the style of joro if they were not allowed to put on the colors of the Imperial families.

sen.j: 特に大上臈は仙洞（上皇御所）および執柄家（摂関家）におかれた女房（豊臣は摂関家の一つと捉えられていた。）。
sen.e: In particular, 'dai-joro' refers to court ladies of higher ranks who served in the Sento Palace (the Palace for a Retired Emperor) or for Sipperi-ke, or Sekkan-ke (the families which produced regents/ the Toyotomi clan was considered one of Sekkan-ke at that time).

In particular, 'dai-joro' refers to court ladies of higher ranks who served in the Sento Palace (the Palace for a Retired Emperor) or for Sipperi-ke, or Sekkan-ke (the families which produced regents (the Toyotomi clan was considered one of Sekkan-ke at that time).

In particular, 'dai-joro' refers to court ladies of higher ranks who served in the Sento Palace (the Palace for a Retired Emperor) or for Shippei-ke, or Sekkan-ke (the families which produced regents [the Toyotomi clan was considered one of Sekkan-ke at that time.])
sen.cmt: Sipperi→Shippei括弧内の括弧を[]に変更

sen.j: 以上、『官職要解』より。
sen.e: The above definition was excerpted from "Guide to Titles of Officials."
The above definition was excerpted from "Guide to Titles of Officials."
The above definition was excerpted from "Guide to Titles of Officials."

sen.j: 12歳で秀頼のもとへ出仕。
sen.e: She started serving Hideyori at the age of twelve.
She started serving Hideyori at the age of twelve.
She started serving Hideyori at the age of 12.

sen.j: 翌年、秀頼公参内に同車にて参内。
sen.e: In the following year, she accompanied Lord Hideyori to the Imperial Palace by Hideyori's sedan chair.
In the following year, she accompanied Lord Hideyori to the Imperial Palace in his sedan chair.
In the following year, she accompanied Lord Hideyori to the Imperial Palace in his sedan chair.

sen.j: 公家衆より武士の娘を参内するとはと非難された。
sen.e: Her visit to the Imperial Palace was blamed by the nobility because she was a daughter from the warrior class.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: Her visit to the Imperial Palace was criticized by the court nobles because she was a daughter from the warrior class.
Her visit to the Imperial Palace was criticized by the court nobles because she was a daughter from the warrior class.

sen.j: しかし、陽光院勅定により平重盛の子孫のため仮親を立てずとも参内可能という特例を得た。
sen.e: Upon the decree of ex-Emperor Yokoin, however, as a special case, it became possible for her to visit the Imperial Palace without the endorsement of the nobility as their tentative child because she was a descendant of TAIRA no Shigemori.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: However, a decree by ex-Emperor Yokoin made it possible for her to visit the Imperial Palace as a special case without appointing adoptive parents because she was a descendant of TAIRA no Shigemori.
sen.cmt: Poor translation.Completely retranslated to reflect source text.
sen.e: However, a decree by ex-Emperor Yokoin made it possible for her to visit the Imperial Palace as a special case without appointing adoptive parents because she was a descendant of TAIRA no Shigemori.

sen.j: 『寛政諸家系図伝』によると、菊ははじめ淀殿に「宮仕え」し、大上臈の列に列して参内した。
sen.e: According to "Kansei Compilation of Genealogies of Vassals in Edo Bakufu," Kiku at first became "an aide to royal" Lady Yodo and visited the Imperial Palace as a member of a retinue of dai-joro.
According to "Kansei Compilation of Genealogies of Vassals in Edo Bakufu," Kiku at first "entered the service of" Lady Yodo and visited the Imperial Palace as a member of a retinue of dai-joro.

According to "Kansei Compilation of Genealogies of Vassals in Edo Bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun)," Kiku at first 'entered the service of' Lady Yodo and visited the Imperial Palace as a member of a retinue of dai-joro.

sen.j: 庶民出身のものはみな公家を仮親とした。
sen.e: Convention demanded that waiting women from non-nobility classes should be endorsed by the nobility as their tentative children.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: All maidservants who were commoners took court nobles as adoptive parents.
All maidservants who were commoners took court nobles as adoptive parents.

sen.j: 菊は特別仮親を持たず、天皇の勅で大上臈となった。
sen.e: Kiku, however, had no particular tentative father of the nobility, and was appointed as dai-joro upon the Imperial decree.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: However, Kiku did not have an adoptive father, and was appointed as dai-joro by imperial decree.
However, Kiku did not have an adoptive father, and was appointed as dai-joro by imperial decree.

sen.j: 三ヶ月奉公し、「弁宰相阿古大上臈」の官位を得る
sen.e: She served in the Imperial Court for three months and was created the official court rank 'Bensaisyo Ako Dai-joro.'
She served in the Imperial Court for three months and was granted the official court rank 'Bensaisyo Ako Dai-joro.'
She served in the Imperial Court for three months and was granted the official court rank 'Bensaisyo Ako Dai-joro.'

sen.j: 大坂の陣では山里曲輪の糒蔵にて秀頼・淀殿と共に命運を共にした（36歳）。
sen.e: In the Osaka no Jin (The Siege of Osaka), Okogo no Tsubone committed suicide (at the age of 36) together with Lord Hideyori and Lady Yodo inside the food storage in the gardening quarter of the (Osaka) castle.

During the Osaka no Jin (The Siege of Osaka), Okogo no Tsubone committed suicide (at the age of 36) together with Lord Hideyori and Lady Yodo inside the food storehouse in the gardening quarter of the (Osaka) castle.
sen.cmt: In > DuringChanged double-byte space to single-byte spacestorage > storehouse
sen.e: During the Osaka no Jin (The Siege of Osaka), Okogo no Tsubone committed suicide (at the age of 36) together with Lord Hideyori and Lady Yodo inside the food storehouse in the gardening quarter of the (Osaka) castle.

sen.j: 大坂城の祠には「三十二義士」の一人として残る。
sen.e: She was enshrined as one of '32 Loyal Retainers' at a small shrine in Osaka Castle.
She was enshrined as one of '32 Loyal Retainers' at a small shrine in Osaka Castle.
She was enshrined as one of '32 Loyal Retainers' at a small shrine in Osaka-jo Castle.

sen.j: 院号を青松院という。
sen.e: Her ingo (a title of respect given to close female relatives of the Emperor or a woman of comparable standing) is 'Seisho-in.'
Her ingo (a title of respect given to close female relatives of the Emperor or a woman of comparable standing) is 'Seisho-in.'
Her ingo (a title of respect given to close female relatives of the Emperor or a woman of comparable standing) is 'Seishoin.'

sen.j: 菩提寺は北野神社および青松院。
sen.e: Her ancestral temples are Kitano-jinja Shrine and Sheisho-in Temple.
Her ancestral temples are Kitano-jinja Shrine and Sheisho-in Temple.
Her ancestral temples are Kitano-jinja Shrine and Sheisho-in Temple.

sen.j: 淀殿自筆書状に見える署名について「あこ」と読めるものがある。
sen.e: There are letters written by Lady Yodo with the signature that can be read 'Ako' (alternative pronunciation of 'Oko').
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: There are letters written by Lady Yodo with a signature that can be read 'Ako' (alternative pronunciation of 'Oko').
There are letters written by Lady Yodo with a signature that can be read 'Ako' (alternative pronunciation of 'Oko').

sen.j: この菊の代筆、もしくは淀殿が菊の名を借りたものとする説がある。
sen.e: As for these letters, there is a belief that they were written by Kiku, or that Lady Yodo wrote these letters under the name of Kiku.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: There is a belief that these letters were written by Kiku, or that Lady Yodo wrote these letters under the name of Kiku.
There is a belief that these letters were written by Kiku, or that Lady Yodo wrote these letters under the name of Kiku.

sen.j: （「あこ」ではなく「よと」であるとの説もある）
sen.e: (There is another belief that the signature is not 'Ako' but 'Yoto.'
There is another belief that the signature is not 'Ako' but 'Yoto.'
There is another belief that the signature is not 'Ako' but 'Yoto.'

sen.j: 桑田忠親は侍女の代筆であるとする。
sen.e: Tadachika KUWATA insists that these letters were written by a waiting woman.
Tadachika KUWATA insists that these letters were written by a maidservant.
Tadachika KUWATA insists that these letters were written by a maidservant.

sen.j: なお、「あこ」の名が見えるとされる書状は、下記のとおりである。
sen.e: Incidentally, the letters with the signature that can be read 'Ako' are:
The letters with a signature that can be read 'Ako' are:
The letters with a signature that can be read 'Ako' are as follows:
sen.cmt: 「下記のとおりである。」原文、訳文に追記しました。

sen.j: 1. 伊勢国慶光院文書、周養上人宛て淀殿自筆消息（慶長9年7月）
sen.e: 1. Lady Yodo's autograph letter (written in July 1604) addressed to Shuyo Shonin (Shuyo, a female bonze of rank), which was housed in Keko-in Convent in Ise Province.
1. A letter written by Lady Yodo (in July 1604) addressed to Shuyo Shonin (Shuyo, a female bonze of rank), which was housed in Keko-in Convent in Ise Province.
1. A letter written by Lady Yodo (in July 1604) addressed to Shuyo Shonin (Shuyo, a female bonze of rank), which was housed in Keko-in Convent in Ise Province.

sen.j: 宇治橋の架け替えに関する文書。
sen.e: The letter is about the renovation of the Uji Bridge.
The letter is about the renovation of Uji Bridge.
The letter is about the renovation of Uji-bashi Bridge.

sen.j: 徳川家光誕生を寿ぐ内容が特徴的。
sen.e: It is characterized by the celebration of the birth of Iemitsu TOKUGAWA.
It is characterized by its celebration of the birth of Iemitsu TOKUGAWA.
It is characterized by its celebration of the birth of Iemitsu TOKUGAWA.

sen.j: 2. 知善院所蔵の京極高次宛て淀殿自筆消息（慶長11年）
sen.e: 2. Lady Yodo's autograph letter (written in 1606) addressed to Takatsugu KYOGOKU, which is housed in Chizen-in Temple
2. A letter written by Lady Yodo (in 1606) addressed to Takatsugu KYOGOKU, which is housed in Chizen-in Temple.
2. A letter written by Lady Yodo (in 1606) addressed to Takatsugu KYOGOKU, which is housed in Chizen-in Temple.

sen.j: 内容は高次への私信。
sen.e: The letter is personal communication addressed to Takatsugu.
It is personal communication addressed to Takatsugu.
It is personal communication addressed to Takatsugu.

sen.j: 京極忠高への祝いのことについて。
sen.e: It is about congratulations to Tadataka KYOGOKU.
It is a letter of congratulation to Tadataka KYOGOKU..
It is a letter of congratulation to Tadataka KYOGOKU..
